head.title: Elegy.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 25, 1796), p. 4. David Radcliffe reads Turnbull’s "Elegy” as one of many responses to Thomas Gray’s An Elegy wrote in a Country Churchyard (1751): the “life argument” Turnbull develops is implicit in Gray’s elegy and, like Gray, Turnbull relies of a series of verse characters (Spenser and the Tradition).

lg.l: To earthly bliss, how various are the ways,
So many schemes allure the human mind!
Which, as we follow through life’s giddy maze,
The phantom flies and leaves us far behind.
The greedy abject slave of sordid gain,
Unnumber’d daring artifices tries,
Undaunted braves the dangers of the main,
And barters quiet for the golden prize.
Obsequious, one at pleasure’s magic call,
The fleeting hours in revelry beguiles;
Conducts the blooming beauty through the ball,
And counts his treasure in his fair one’s smiles.
The meagre student, by the lamp’s pale light,
Eager the depths of science to explore,
Deny’d the balmy blessings of the night,

Still turns the sapient volume22 Enrag’d the rustic rout, with foul despight, / From Palinode the sapient volume tore,” from a short poem in praise of Spenser in “To the Editor: Remarks on the Opinion of Dr. Johnson concerning the Imitation of Spenser,” Edinburgh Magazine or Literary Miscellany, VI (August, 1787), p. 50. Turnbull uses the phrase recurrently; cf. “Elegy I,” line 20 and “The Vicissitudes of Fortune,” line 134, in Poetical Essays (1788) and “Epilogue” Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 1, 1796), line 11. o’er and o’er.
Those whom the noble thoughts of glory fire,
Pursue, in martial fields, a deathless name;
And where unnumber’d multitudes expire,
They rear the purple column of their fame.
Ne’er did the love of wealth my peace destroy,
I ne’er was fir’d with mighty feats of arms:
Be mine sweet quiet and domestic joy,
Far from the busy crowd and war’s alarms.
And would inspiring Phoebus,33 God of light, or the sun. son of Jove,44 Poetical equivalent of the Roman god Jupiter, i.e., Apollo.
Teach me to tune the soul enchanting lyre,
Nature to paint or pour the song of love,
’Tis all the gift, ye Gods, that I desire.
To woo the muse from dawn ’till closing day,
To deck the paths immortal bards have trod,
With Fancy, bright Aerieal maid, to stray,
And trace her footsteps in the flow’ry road.
Come then, O come, sweet Muses to my aid,
Teach me the pensive moments to employ,
To frame the verse beneath the woodland shade.
Be thou, sweet Poetry, my love, my joy.
